rationales.tradition: Soo-jin accepted the grandmother's banana milk and thanked her properly 'the way my mom taught me,' honoring a culturally transmitted practice of respectful interaction with elders.

rationales.self_direction: Soo-jin continues to reject her friend Eunji's offer of a stable marketing job because sitting in an office doing work she doesn't care about creates a 'weight in my chest,' choosing creative autonomy over conventional employment.
rationales.security: She acknowledges rent is due, the math never adds up, and she made only 40,000 won today, yet refuses to take the stable full-time position with salary and benefits that would resolve her financial precarity.

rationales.conformity: Soo-jin kept scrolling past a racist slur in the driver group chat because she needs these people for shift swaps, restraining herself to avoid conflict in a work setting.
rationales.universalism: She witnessed a slur directed at a Vietnamese restaurant owner and chose not to speak up against the prejudice, failing to defend someone from a marginalized group.

rationales.security: Soo-jin took the streetwear job primarily to cover rent, her phone bill, and a debt to Eunji, prioritizing financial stability over her principles.
rationales.universalism: She accepted work designing branding for a company with exploitative supply chains in Myanmar and Bangladesh, despite knowing the human cost and personally helping workers from those same countries on Saturdays.

rationales.benevolence: Soo-jin deliberately did not offer to help Sophy document her unsafe factory conditions, withdrawing from someone in her close community because engaging felt hypocritical given the streetwear job.
rationales.universalism: She let the conversation about factory safety violations move on without following up, allowing injustice to go unaddressed because she felt complicit in the same exploitative system.

Soo-jin acknowledges she chose the paycheck over her beliefs about exploitative supply chains, and her response 'knowing better doesn't change what I do' reveals conscious acceptance of acting against broader human welfare.
